title: Jeremiah Chapter 7 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 7 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 7 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 7.

questions.question: Where was Jeremiah instructed to stand and proclaim the word of the LORD?
options: At the gate of the LORD's house
questions.correctAnswer: At the gate of the LORD's house
questions.explanation: Jeremiah was told to stand in the gate of the LORD'S house and proclaim the word (Jeremiah 7:2).

questions.question: What did the LORD say He would cause the people to do if they amended their ways and doings?
questions.correctAnswer: Dwell in this place
questions.explanation: God promised that if they amend their ways, He would cause them to dwell in this place (Jeremiah 7:3).

questions.question: What were the people warned not to trust in, according to Jeremiah 7:4?
questions.correctAnswer: Lying words
questions.explanation: The LORD warned them not to trust in lying words saying, 'The temple of the LORD' (Jeremiah 7:4).

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 7:6, which groups should not be oppressed?
options: The stranger, the fatherless, and the widow
questions.correctAnswer: The stranger, the fatherless, and the widow
questions.explanation: The LORD commanded that they should not oppress the stranger, the fatherless, and the widow (Jeremiah 7:6).

questions.question: What did God say the people were doing in the house called by His name?
options: Making it a den of robbers
questions.correctAnswer: Making it a den of robbers
questions.explanation: God said He saw that the house called by His name had become a den of robbers (Jeremiah 7:11).

questions.question: Where did God tell Jeremiah to go and look to see what He did for wickedness of His people Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Shiloh
questions.explanation: God told Jeremiah to go to His place in Shiloh and see what He did for the wickedness of Israel (Jeremiah 7:12).

questions.question: What did God say He would do to the house which is called by His name and where they trust?
options: Do as He did to Shiloh
Make it a place of blessing
questions.correctAnswer: Do as He did to Shiloh
questions.explanation: Because they did evil, God said He would do to this house as He did to Shiloh (Jeremiah 7:14).

questions.question: What did God instruct Jeremiah not to do for the people anymore?
questions.correctAnswer: Pray or intercede
questions.explanation: God told Jeremiah not to pray or make intercession for the people because He would not hear him (Jeremiah 7:16).

questions.question: Who did the children make cakes to, according to Jeremiah 7:18?
questions.correctAnswer: The queen of heaven
questions.explanation: The children made cakes to the queen of heaven as part of their idolatry (Jeremiah 7:18).

questions.question: What will be poured out upon the place, man, beast, and trees as a result of their sins?
questions.correctAnswer: Anger and fury
questions.explanation: God declared that His anger and fury would be poured out upon the place, man, beast, and trees (Jeremiah 7:20).

questions.question: True or False: God commanded burnt offerings and sacrifices when He brought the fathers out of Egypt.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: God said He did not command burnt offerings or sacrifices when He brought the fathers out of Egypt (Jeremiah 7:22).

questions.question: True or False: The main command God gave to the fathers was to obey His voice and walk in His ways.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: God commanded obedience to His voice and walking in His ways so that it might be well with them (Jeremiah 7:23).

questions.question: True or False: The people listened and obeyed the prophets God sent throughout their history.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The people did not listen or obey the prophets sent by God; they hardened their necks instead (Jeremiah 7:25-26).

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'Cut off thine ______, O Jerusalem, and cast it away, and take up a lamentation on high places...'
questions.correctAnswer: hair
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:29 says to cut off thine hair, cast it away, and lament on high places.

questions.question: What was built in the valley of the son of Hinnom for evil purposes?
questions.correctAnswer: The high places of Tophet
questions.explanation: They built high places of Tophet in the valley of Hinnom to burn their children, which God did not command (Jeremiah 7:31).

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 7 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 7 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 7 teach us about the importance of genuine repentance and obedience?
options: Amend your ways and doings to dwell in the land
Trust in the temple's protection alone
Offer more sacrifices to be forgiven
Ignore others and focus on personal worship
questions.correctAnswer: Amend your ways and doings to dwell in the land
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:3 calls for amending ways and doings to dwell securely (7:3, 7:5-7, 7:23). Trusting merely in the temple or sacrifices without obedience is rejected (7:4, 7:21-24).

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with trusting in religious rituals but neglecting justice. Based on Jeremiah 7, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Execute justice and do not oppress the vulnerable
Rely on temple rituals alone for God's favor
Avoid public worship and pray privately only
questions.correctAnswer: Execute justice and do not oppress the vulnerable
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:5-6 emphasizes executing judgment and not oppressing strangers, orphans, and widows as essential to God's favor, rather than just ritual worship (7:3, 7:21-23).

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 7 warn against false trust in religious places without true faith?
options: Do not trust in lying words about the temple
Trust only in the priests' prayers
Only the temple matters, not actions
questions.correctAnswer: Do not trust in lying words about the temple
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:4 and 7:8 warn against trusting lying words about the temple alone, highlighting that mere location or ritual does not guarantee God's favor without true repentance and obedience (7:3, 7:11).

questions.question: What teaching from Jeremiah 7 applies to maintaining integrity in daily life and relationships?
options: Do not steal, murder, swear falsely, or commit adultery
Trust in religious status for protection
questions.correctAnswer: Do not steal, murder, swear falsely, or commit adultery
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:9 lists sins like stealing, murder, adultery, and false swearing as actions incompatible with true worship and integrity, teaching the importance of honesty and moral conduct (7:5-6, 7:23).

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 7 illustrate the consequences of ignoring God's commands despite warnings?
options: God will cast out the disobedient as He did Israel
questions.correctAnswer: God will cast out the disobedient as He did Israel
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:14-15 and 7:25-26 show God’s judgment on disobedient people who reject His prophets, comparing their fate to Israel's exile and punishment (7:12, 7:13, 7:24).

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 7 teach about prayer and intercession for a rebellious people?
options: Do not pray or intercede because God will not hear
questions.correctAnswer: Do not pray or intercede because God will not hear
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:16 instructs Jeremiah not to pray or intercede for the people because God will not listen due to their persistent rebellion (7:13, 7:26-27).

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 7 encourages worshippers to continue their sacrifices and burnt offerings as commanded from Egypt.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:21-22 clarifies that God did not command burnt offerings or sacrifices at the time of the Exodus; He commanded obedience and walking in His ways instead.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 7 exposes that the people were provoking God to anger by worshipping the queen of heaven and other gods.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:18-19 describe how the people worshipped the queen of heaven and other gods, provoking God's anger and their own confusion.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 7 teach humility in acknowledging God's authority over worship and obedience?
options: Obey God's voice and walk in His ways
Ignore God's commands for personal gain
Add more sacrifices to gain favor
questions.correctAnswer: Obey God's voice and walk in His ways
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:23 emphasizes obedience to God's voice and walking in His ways as the key to being His people and receiving blessing (7:3, 7:24).

questions.question: A believer faces temptation to follow false gods and practices. What guidance does Jeremiah 7 give regarding such temptation?
options: Do not walk after other gods to your hurt
Blend false worship with true worship
Trust the temple to protect from harm
questions.correctAnswer: Do not walk after other gods to your hurt
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:6-7 and 7:9 warn against following other gods, which leads to harm and God's judgment, teaching steadfastness in faithfulness to God alone.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 7, what is the role of justice and kindness in living faithfully before God?
options: Execute judgment and do not oppress the vulnerable
questions.correctAnswer: Execute judgment and do not oppress the vulnerable
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:5-6 instructs to practice justice between neighbors and not oppress strangers, orphans, or widows, linking faithful living with righteous social conduct.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah 7 tells us to 'Obey my voice, and I will be your God, and ye shall be my people: and walk ye in all the ways that I have commanded you, that it may be ____ unto you.'
questions.correctAnswer: well
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:23 highlights that obedience to God's voice and commandments leads to well-being ('that it may be well unto you').

questions.question: What practical lesson about stewardship and worship does Jeremiah 7 offer regarding burnt offerings and sacrifices?
options: God values obedience over burnt offerings
Sacrifices are the only way to atonement
Ignore God's commands and rely on offerings
questions.correctAnswer: God values obedience over burnt offerings
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:21-23 teaches that God did not command burnt offerings but obedience and walking in His ways, emphasizing heart obedience over ritual.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 7 encourage believers to respond when others provoke God through idolatry and sin?
options: Recognize the danger and call for repentance
Trust that God will overlook it
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize the danger and call for repentance
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:18-20 warns of God's anger against idolatry and sin, encouraging believers to acknowledge the danger and repent (7:27-28).

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 7 say about the future of the land and people if they continue in rebellion?
options: The land will be desolate with no joy or gladness
questions.correctAnswer: The land will be desolate with no joy or gladness
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:34 predicts the cessation of joy, gladness, and celebration in Judah due to their sin, leading to desolation and judgment (7:32-33).

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 7 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 7.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 7, what action does the LORD command Jeremiah to take at the gate of the LORD's house?
options: Proclaim the word of the LORD to all who enter to worship
Offer burnt offerings on behalf of the people
Build an altar to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Proclaim the word of the LORD to all who enter to worship
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:2 states that Jeremiah was commanded to stand in the gate of the LORD's house and proclaim the word of the LORD to those who enter to worship.

questions.question: What condition does the LORD set for the people to continue dwelling in the land He gave to their fathers?
options: They must amend their ways and execute justice between neighbors
They must build a new temple
They must strictly observe the Sabbath
questions.correctAnswer: They must amend their ways and execute justice between neighbors
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:3-5 explains that if the people amend their ways and execute judgment between man and neighbor, they will dwell in the land forever.

questions.question: Jeremiah 7 warns against trusting in what kind of words regarding the temple of the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Lying words
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:4 and 7:8 warn the people not to trust in lying words that say, 'The temple of the LORD, the temple of the LORD, the temple of the LORD' and that cannot profit.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 7, what is the LORD's view of the temple becoming a 'den of robbers'?
options: The LORD has seen it and condemns it
It is a sign of prosperity
It is a place of safety for the people
It is acceptable as long as sacrifices continue
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD has seen it and condemns it
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:11 states that the house called by the LORD's name has become a den of robbers and that the LORD has seen it, indicating His condemnation.

questions.question: What historical location does the LORD refer to as an example of judgment for wickedness?
questions.correctAnswer: Shiloh
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:12 references the place in Shiloh where the LORD set His name at first and what was done to it because of Israel's wickedness.

questions.question: What is the LORD's instruction to Jeremiah regarding praying for the people amid their rebellion?
options: Do not pray or make intercession for them
questions.correctAnswer: Do not pray or make intercession for them
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:16 instructs Jeremiah not to pray for the people or make intercession because the LORD will not hear him due to their persistent disobedience.

questions.question: Jeremiah 7 describes the people making cakes and pouring out drink offerings to whom?
questions.correctAnswer: The queen of heaven
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:18 describes children gathering wood, fathers kindling fire, and women kneading dough to make cakes to the queen of heaven and pouring out drink offerings to other gods.

questions.question: Which of the following punishments does the LORD declare will be poured out upon the land and its inhabitants?
options: Anger and fury that shall burn and not be quenched
questions.correctAnswer: Anger and fury that shall burn and not be quenched
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:20 declares the LORD's anger and fury will be poured out upon the place, man, beast, trees, and fruit of the ground, burning without being quenched.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 7, what was the primary command from God to the fathers when He brought them out of Egypt?
options: Obey my voice and walk in my ways
questions.correctAnswer: Obey my voice and walk in my ways
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:22-23 clarifies that God did not command burnt offerings or sacrifices at the exodus but commanded obedience to His voice and walking in His ways.

questions.question: What literary device is evident in the repeated phrase 'The temple of the LORD, The temple of the LORD, The temple of the LORD' in Jeremiah 7:4?
questions.correctAnswer: Repetition for emphasis
questions.explanation: The triple repetition in Jeremiah 7:4 is a literary device emphasizing the false trust placed in the temple, highlighting the people's misplaced confidence.

questions.question: Jeremiah 7:25-26 describes the people's response to the prophets sent by God. How did they respond?
options: They did not listen and hardened their necks
They built altars to honor the prophets
questions.correctAnswer: They did not listen and hardened their necks
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:25-26 states that despite God's sending prophets daily, the people did not listen, inclined not their ears, and hardened their necks.

questions.question: The reference to Tophet in Jeremiah 7:31 is significant because it was a place associated with what practice?
questions.correctAnswer: Burning children as sacrifices
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:31 condemns the building of high places of Tophet in the valley of Hinnom to burn sons and daughters in fire, an abomination not commanded by God.

questions.question: What is the predicted outcome for Jerusalem as described at the end of Jeremiah 7?
options: The city will become desolate with no voices of joy
It will be rebuilt and prosperous
It will be a center of worship for all nations
It will be spared from destruction
questions.correctAnswer: The city will become desolate with no voices of joy
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:34 prophesies that the voice of mirth, gladness, bridegroom, and bride will cease in the cities of Judah and Jerusalem, and the land will be desolate.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 7 teaches that God commanded burnt offerings and sacrifices when He brought the fathers out of Egypt.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:22 states that God did not command burnt offerings or sacrifices at the day of the exodus; instead, He commanded obedience to His voice.

questions.question: Which theme is strongly developed in Jeremiah 7 regarding the relationship between ritual worship and ethical behavior?
options: Ethical behavior must accompany worship for it to be accepted
Ritual worship alone guarantees God's favor
Sacrifices are more important than obedience
Worship should be secret and individual
questions.correctAnswer: Ethical behavior must accompany worship for it to be accepted
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:5-6 emphasizes the need to amend ways, execute justice, and avoid oppression, showing worship without ethical conduct is rejected by God.

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 7 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 7 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the primary condition God sets for the people of Judah to continue dwelling in the land He gave their fathers?
options: Amend your ways and your doings
Offer more burnt offerings and sacrifices
Build more altars in the land
questions.correctAnswer: Amend your ways and your doings
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:3 states that God calls the people to amend their ways and doings so He will allow them to dwell in the land. This reflects the biblical theme that obedience to God's commands is foundational to covenant blessing (Deut 30:16; Ezek 18:21-23; Matt 7:21; James 1:22).

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 7, what false confidence are the people of Judah placing their trust in?
options: Lying words that the temple alone will save them
questions.correctAnswer: Lying words that the temple alone will save them
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:4 and 7:8 reveal that the people trust in 'lying words,' specifically the repeated claim 'The temple of the LORD, The temple of the LORD, The temple of the LORD.' This misplaced confidence neglects true repentance and justice (Isaiah 29:13; Matthew 15:8-9; Mark 7:6-7; Hosea 6:6).

questions.question: Which social injustices does God specifically condemn in Jeremiah 7 as reasons that provoke His anger?
options: Oppressing the stranger, the fatherless, and the widow, and shedding innocent blood
Failing to give tithes and offerings
questions.correctAnswer: Oppressing the stranger, the fatherless, and the widow, and shedding innocent blood
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:6 highlights God’s hatred of social injustice, emphasizing care for vulnerable groups and the prohibition of innocent bloodshed. This aligns with the consistent biblical teaching on justice and mercy (Exodus 22:21-24; Psalm 82:3-4; James 1:27; Micah 6:8).

questions.question: What metaphor does God use to describe the temple when condemning the people's hypocrisy in worship?
questions.correctAnswer: A den of robbers
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:11 states that the temple, which is called by God's name, has become a 'den of robbers,' indicating corruption and exploitation where holiness should dwell. Jesus later uses the same metaphor in Matthew 21:13 to condemn temple abuses, affirming God's disdain for hypocritical worship.

questions.question: What historical place does God instruct Jeremiah to visit as a warning to Judah about their current disobedience?
questions.correctAnswer: Shiloh
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:12 refers to Shiloh, the place where God first set His name, as a warning example of judgment for wickedness. This recalls Israel’s early history (1 Samuel 1:3; Psalm 78:60-61) and serves as a typological warning that disobedience leads to divine judgment (Hebrews 3:7-11).

questions.question: What is God's response to Jeremiah's request to pray for the people of Judah?
options: God will not hear the prayers for this people
God will send a new prophet
questions.correctAnswer: God will not hear the prayers for this people
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:16 commands Jeremiah not to pray or intercede for the people because God will not hear him. This reflects a judgment phase where God's patience is withdrawn due to persistent rebellion (Isaiah 1:15-20; Ezekiel 14:3-8; Romans 1:18-21).

questions.question: What idolatrous practice involving the 'queen of heaven' is condemned in this chapter?
options: Making cakes and pouring out drink offerings to her
Building high altars for her worship
Wearing her image as an amulet
questions.correctAnswer: Making cakes and pouring out drink offerings to her
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:18 describes children, fathers, and women making cakes and pouring out drink offerings to the queen of heaven, an idolatrous practice that provokes God’s anger. This reflects syncretism condemned throughout Scripture (Exodus 34:14; 2 Kings 23:13; Acts 19:26).

questions.question: What is the ultimate consequence God pronounces on the land and its inhabitants in Jeremiah 7?
options: His anger and fury will be poured out; the land will be desolate
They will be blessed with peace and prosperity
They will be exiled but restored within a year
They will conquer their enemies through divine aid
questions.correctAnswer: His anger and fury will be poured out; the land will be desolate
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:20 and 7:34 describe God's judgment as unquenchable fire burning the land and the cessation of joy in the cities, leading to desolation. This eschatological judgment motif aligns with themes in Isaiah 24:1-6, Ezekiel 7:18-27, and Revelation 6:12-17.

questions.question: What does God say about burnt offerings and sacrifices in this chapter?
options: God did not command burnt offerings or sacrifices at the Exodus but commanded obedience
Burnt offerings must be doubled to gain favor
Sacrifices are the only way to cleanse sin
Burnt offerings replace obedience to God
questions.correctAnswer: God did not command burnt offerings or sacrifices at the Exodus but commanded obedience
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:21-23 clarify that God’s original command was obedience, not ritual sacrifices, emphasizing covenant faithfulness over external rites. This is consistent with Hosea 6:6, Psalm 40:6, and Hebrews 10:5-10 teaching that God desires obedience and a changed heart.

questions.question: How do the people of Judah respond to God's prophets according to Jeremiah 7?
options: They do not listen and harden their necks
They immediately repent and return to God
They build altars to honor the prophets
They write down the prophecies and keep them
questions.correctAnswer: They do not listen and harden their necks
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:25-26 describes the people as rejecting God's messengers and hardening their necks, an expression of stubborn rebellion. This theme is echoed in Exodus 32:9, Isaiah 63:10, and Acts 7:51, demonstrating human resistance to God's revelation.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah say about the nation's relationship to the truth in this chapter?
options: Truth is perished and cut off from their mouth
Truth is highly honored and cherished
Truth is kept separate from falsehood
Truth is hidden but preserved for the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: Truth is perished and cut off from their mouth
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:28 states that the nation does not obey God’s voice nor receive correction, and truth is perished and cut off from their mouth. This reflects spiritual decay and is consistent with Proverbs 12:22, Isaiah 59:3, and John 8:44 on the prevalence of falsehood in rebellion.

questions.question: What symbolic action does Jeremiah command Jerusalem to perform as a sign of mourning and judgment?
options: Cut off your hair and cast it away
questions.correctAnswer: Cut off your hair and cast it away
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:29 commands the cutting off of hair as a symbol of lamentation and rejection by God. This custom symbolizes mourning and is seen elsewhere in Scripture (Isaiah 15:2; Ezekiel 7:18; Amos 8:10).

questions.question: What horrific practice in the valley of the son of Hinnom is condemned in this chapter?
options: Burning their sons and daughters in fire
questions.correctAnswer: Burning their sons and daughters in fire
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:31 condemns child sacrifice in the valley of Hinnom, a practice God never commanded and abhors. This is consistent with Leviticus 18:21, Deuteronomy 12:31, and Psalm 106:37-38 denouncing human sacrifice.

questions.question: What new name does God say the valley of the son of Hinnom will be called because of judgment?
questions.correctAnswer: The valley of slaughter
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:32 declares that the valley of Hinnom will no longer be called Tophet but the valley of slaughter due to the coming judgment. This renaming signifies divine wrath and is echoed in prophetic judgment themes (Isaiah 66:24; Ezekiel 39:17-20; Revelation 19:17-18).

questions.question: What will happen to the carcasses of the people after God's judgment as described in Jeremiah 7?
options: They will be food for the fowls of heaven and beasts of the earth
They will be buried with honor
questions.correctAnswer: They will be food for the fowls of heaven and beasts of the earth
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 7:33 predicts that the carcasses of the people will become food for birds and beasts, a vivid symbol of defeat and disgrace (Deuteronomy 28:26; Ezekiel 39:4-20; Revelation 19:21). This imagery conveys the totality of God's judgment.
